Aww... I always get suckered by "robot".

Those are just big, oddly shaped vehicles.
so, Gundam versus robots from Avatar movie...great...

I hope this will be more interesting than that "giant robot fighting" reality show from last year. I'd like to see this be an actual fight to total destruction rather than whatever weird rules they had for that game (which seemed completely scripted, btw). The one robot was demoing shooting paintballs for crying out loud. 

I can't see how this will ever be actual combat since there's actually people inside. Unless both teams have agreed to do this thing on Sealand and nobody cares if they get maimed or killed.

> Aww... I always get suckered by "robot".

What defines the line for you? A normal printer is a robot too, as are many other things. If really depends or your definition.

Though most people's views of robots will be driven by Hollywoord and anime concepts, creating a fairly wild idea of how one should look and act.

> 
> What defines the line for you? A normal printer is a robot too, as are many other things. If really depends or your definition.
> Though most people's views of robots will be driven by Hollywoord and anime concepts, creating a fairly wild idea of how one should look and act.

It has nothing to do with Hollywood. A robot can be programmed and then left to do it's thing with little oversight. 

Those things are as much a robot as your car is. You sit inside it and control it's every move. Just because it's a machine does not make it a "robot".

Edit: And yes, cars are becoming significantly more "robotic" but I'm sure you get the point.

> 
> Those things are as much a robot as your car is.

This is exactly my point. A car is actually quite an advanced robot already, as it can perform a lot of simple and complicated functions automatically. It is, in quite a few senses, much more a robot than a factory robot is. You are just used to robots looking like robots because of the Hollywood bias most people have.

> 
> Those things are as much a robot as your car is. You sit inside it and control it's every move. Just because it's a machine does not make it a "robot".Edit: And yes, cars are becoming significantly more "robotic" but I'm sure you get the point.

Mech is probably a better term, but FFS, FASA probably has a copyright on the word. 

But... yeah. A vehicle that has legs instead of wheels. That still makes it really freaking cool though, no matter what you call it.

> 
> This is exactly my point. A car is actually quite an advanced robot already, as it can perform a lot of simple and complicated functions automatically. It is, in quite a few senses, much more a robot than a factory robot is. You are just used to robots looking like robots because of the Hollywood bias most people have.

It doesn't have anything to do with "looking like a robot". They are nothing but vehicles/machines/contraptions/puppets. That's why they are not robots.

And like I said, yes, cars are becoming more robotic quite quickly, but I still think you easily understand the point, and it's really stretching to call your car a robot. The day you can sit in it and tell it where to go, then read a book, you can really call it a robot.

Are you two arguing about what a robot makes a robot?

I don't want to sound rude but this thread is not the right one for this kind of discussion.

It's very probable that the "fight" will be rigged just like wrestling shows. Those robots are just too expensive to just trash them. Also the MegaBot is powered by a gasoline engine. If it or the tank get damaged the robot could burn up with the two pilots inside.

So I wonder what kind of duel it will be. The Kuratas guys want to have a melee battle but the MegaBot has guns instead of arms. Therefore a real melee fight will be out of question. I can only think of a kind of paint ball gun battle. But that would be boring as both robots have really slow movement.

What do you expect to see?
